ETYMOLOGY: From 'rail' (from Old French raille or Germanic ragel 'bar, plank') and 'way' (from Old English weg 'path'). The compound 'railway' emerged to describe the tracks made of rails for transport, eventually encompassing the entire system.
SINCE: Late 18th century (early forms), early 19th century (established system)

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A noun is a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A track or set of tracks made of steel rails, along which trains run.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 由钢轨铺设的轨道或轨道系统，火车在其上运行。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The new high-speed railway connects the two major cities.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 新建的高速铁路连接着这两个主要城市。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A noun is a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A system of transport using special tracks for trains, along with the trains, stations, and managing organization.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 指使用专门轨道运行火车的运输系统，包括火车、车站及管理机构。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Many people rely on the railway for their daily commute.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 许多人依靠铁路进行日常通勤。

REGISTER: Commonly used in British English. In American English, "railroad" is more frequently used, though "railway" is also understood.
